body.p: We thank to Gundogan et al for their interest and contribution to our study. Our aim was mainly to determine whether there is a retinal thinning in pediatric patients with relapsing remitting multiple sclerosis and whether this atrophy is influenced by optic neuritis. We additionally compared visual evoked potential recordings between subgroups of eyes with and without previous optic neuritis.

Previously Gundogan et al1 reported increased visual evoked potential latencies and decreased amplitudes in adult multiple sclerosis patients without previous optic neuritis as compared to those of healthy controls. As we have not compared visual evoked potential recordings between patients and healthy controls, we could not confirm these results in the pediatric population. Instead, we compared visual evoked potential latency/amplitude values between subgroups and found that visual evoked potential amplitude was significantly reduced in the affected eyes of patients with previous optic neuritis as compared to patients without optic neuritis. However visual evoked potential latency was not found to be significantly different between patients with and without previous optic neuritis. When we performed these comparisons between groups stratified according to time interval from optic neuritis, although visual evoked potential latency was found to be more markedly delayed in patients with a longer time interval from clinical optic neuritis, this delay was not statistically significant, likely because of small sample size (Table 1).

body.p: We have already reported that mean retinal nerve fiber length thickness was reduced in eyes with delayed visual evoked potential latency as compared to eyes with normal visual evoked potential latency, though macular volume was not significantly different between the 2 groups.2 When we compared retinal nerve fiber layer thickness and macular volume between eyes of patients with normal and delayed visual evoked potential latency and healthy controls; mean and all 4 quadrant retinal nerve fiber layer thickness and macular volume were found significantly reduced in eyes with delayed visual evoked potential latency, whereas the reduction was significant only in temporal quadrant retinal nerve fiber layer thickness in patients with normal visual evoked potential latency (Table 2).

caption.p: Comparisons of Mean RNFL Thickness, Quadrant RNFL Thickness, and Macular Volume Values Between Eyes With Normal and Delayed VEP Latency Groups and Eyes of Healthy Controlsa

fn.p: Abbreviations: RNFL, retinal nerve fiber layer; VEP, visual evoked potential.

body.p: As Gundogan et al have requested, we performed correlations between retinal nerve fiber layer thickness/macular volume and visual evoked potential latency and amplitude values in eyes of patients with pediatric multiple sclerosis, and we found no significant correlations (Table 3). Recently Gundogan et al have also reported no correlations in eyes of adult multiple sclerosis patients without previous optic neuritis. However when they have included healthy controls in the analysis, they found that P100 latency was significantly correlated to retinal nerve fiber layer average and retinal nerve fiber layer temporal thicknesses. As we have not performed electrophysiological recordings in healthy controls, we could not include retinal nerve fiber layer thickness/macular volume and visual evoked potential latency and amplitude values of controls in the correlation analysis. From this point of view, our study was not able to show the electrophysiological status of pediatric multiple sclerosis patients in comparison to healthy controls.

body.p: Further studies investigating the electrophysiological status of the patients with multiple sclerosis along with the studies of retinal nerve fiber layer thickness/macular volume to find out the subclinical involvement of visual pathways and the disease itself are needed.
